title: Will computers ever be able to think? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think this question is most interesting if we are talking about artificial consciousness, on a par with or exceeding human consciousness (albeit not necessarily the same). Before I drop a number I think it’s important to point out a couple of circumstances: Historically, people have been excessively optimistic about this, and all predictions of “within 30 years”, and “by the year 2000” and so on have proven to be completely false. To me, this indicates that any gut feelings about it, especially spectacular and optimistic gut feelings, should be met with extreme skepticism.In the heyday of AI, roughly the time before the 90s, people had a completely different mental model of what “thinking” and “consciousness” meant. People used to think that what sets people apart is our ability to think logically and rationally. This was reflected in AI research which focused on expert systems, automatic theorem proving, epistemic logic, and many more kinds of formal reasoning. These efforts, while often useful for their own sake, have fizzled when it comes to creating conscious machines. Basically the period 1950–1990 has taught us that logic is not what it’s about.Current machine learning research takes a more “bottom-up” approach to consciousness, where simple statistical models are used to learn appropriate behaviour in a variety of circumstances, and we have managed to apply such technologies in progressively harder tasks, such as optical character recognition and speech recognition and recommender systems and Go playing algorithms. The deep learning hype is the most recent step in this trend.Machine learning is currently advancing very rapidly, which makes many people optimistic about using it to create conscious software. However there is no way of knowing if our current rapid progress will continue unabated until we manage to come up with a thinking machine, or that there are fundamental problems still ahead that we haven’t really run into headlong yet. We may need yet another paradigm shift such as the one that happened in the 90s!My bet is that there are still fundamental issues that we haven’t even properly realised are a problem yet. How long it would take to solve such issues is anybody’s guess, it could be anywhere from a minor hurdle to almost unsolvable. So my best guess is that we won’t see conscious computers for at least 50–100 more years, but I would not be surprised either if it never happens at all. Verdict: probably not in my lifetime.

A computer program could meet your definition of "think" today, rather trivially. Just have it load up a large knowledge base (say, wikipedia and quora for starters), then have it bounce around randomly within it. In a sense, that's exactly what the Google search engine does when it crawls the web and tries to make sense of it (although the Google search engine is hardly trivial). But then again, you said it has to have "thoughts" on each topic. And the word "thought" is, of course, defined as the product of thinking.  And you defined "thinking" as having (random topic, autonomous) thoughts. So basically you've defined "thinking" circularly, using a forms of the word in its definition. You'll either have to define it better, or accept that computers are able to think today. ----  Edsger Dijkstra said: "The question of whether a computer can think is no more interesting than the question of whether a submarine can swim."  In other words, it's really nothing more than a semantic question: if you want to say that submarines can't swim because you've defined "swim" to only apply to biological organisms, fine, but it's not a particularly interesting conclusion.

Probably. Let's first assume that humans can think. Humans were created through the process of natural selection, so there exists a process by which thinking beings can be created. Now that we have a process, the question is whether humans would be able to duplicate or surpass that process in a reasonable amount of time. This seems highly likely because evolution is incredibly stupid. A student can do things in a few hours that would take evolution millions of years. So it seems pretty reasonable that humans could, at the very least, create some sort of man-made intelligent system within a few thousand years.

Keep in mind you are talking about a machine. Movies (and people) have personified machines for dramatic purposes. The term AI is used with the idea that a machine can be given or create “intelligent” output but in reality its a misnomer because a computer is nothing less than the greatest type of machine ever created but it is still a machine. Machines can be faster than man in terms of automation (processing, repeating tasks, recall) but they will always have a quantifiable output; never qualitative. Anyone who tells you otherwise will be basing their idea on a fantasy.

We have often taken the brute force approach when it comes to examining nature. So I would say that on the day we have processing power strong enough to simulate the human brain, we will be close. Just as a weak comparison, neurons and transistors can be though of the 'unit' of processing for the brain and CPU. The CPU has roughly 2 billion transistors (i.e. 6th gen i7). The brain is estimated to have up to 100 billion neurons. As many will point out, neurons are much more complex than a transistor. I would consider them to be more like little RISC processors. Also, as far as we know, the brain doesn't use binary to communicate between neurons. Rather, it uses a range of values based on the intensity of the chemical reactions between them. Similar to what we see in quantum computing. So basically we are looking for the day we can link 100 billion quantum RISC processors into a single functional unit.

When will computers think? Well, someone coming up with a concrete technical definition for “think” that makes no reference to brains (which have nothing to do with computers) would be a prerequisite. I don’t think this question is answerable until someone manages that. Same problem with musing about computers being “sentient”, “feeling”, being “conscious”, etc. Those are all brain terms, and computers have nothing to do with brains. Until those things are described in hard technical and mathematical terms, they have no more to do with computers than right angles have to do with the colour blue.
If meat can do it, silicon probably can too.

The current architecture to which machines compute makes it nearly impossible to achieve this. Machines execute one instruction after another and know nothing of the previous nor the next instruction. They are unable to understand or gain a contextual view on what is happening. We are able to fool humans into thinking computers can think however it wouldn't mean the computer is able to think. I suggest reading about the Turing Test and the Chinese Room theory.

We need to know how the brain works, only just beginning on this questWhat we have learned so far is that the brain is a massively parallel multiprocessor system with many BILLION processors. Thus2.. We need to be able to build a billion processor system.
